courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Managing Business Data in Excel and Tableau
courses.description: This course will introduce fundamental business data management skills and business intelligence tools that are essential for business management. The course will help students to develop basic concepts of data collection and handling, and to know how to structure and solve business problems using Microsoft Excel and Tableau, the most popular and penetrated tool, with the support of Office 365 for Cloud-based communication. Topics such as Storytelling with Tableau, SharePoint, Formulas and Functions, Charts, Subtotals, PivotTables, PivotCharts, What-If Analysis, Specialized Functions, Statistical Functions, Multiple-Sheet Workbook Management, XML, Power Add-Ins, Workbook Distribution, Templates, Styles, and Macros will be covered.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• To learn the essential operations using Cloud computing through course’s SharePoint Site and Excel
• To develop basic concepts of data collection and data handling
• To learn how to structure and solve business problems using Microsoft Excel
• To develop skills in critical thinking through Discussion Forum of course’s SharePoint Site
• To apply skills to monitor daily business activities using Excel and Tableau through designated course assignments
courses.course_syllabus:
• Course Introduction
• Introduction to Excel Creating and Formatting a Worksheet
• Introduction to SharePoint Site
• Introduction to Tableau Prep + Tableau Desktop
• Formulas and Functions Performing Quantitative Analysis
• Charts Depicting Data Visually
• Datasets and Tables Managing Large Volumes of Data
• Subtotals, PivotTables, and PivotCharts Summarizing and Analyzing Data
• What-If Analysis Using Decision-Making Tools
• Specialized Functions Using Date, Logical, Lookup, and Database
• Statistical Functions Analyzing Statistics
• Multiple-Sheet Workbook Management Ensuring Quality Control
• Imports, XML, and Power Add-Ins Managing Data
• Collaboration and Workbook Distribution Sharing Data with Others
• Templates, Styles, and Macros Standardizing Workbooks
• Exploring Excel data with Tableau, learn a drag-and-drop approach to visual analysis
• Creating Dashboards and Storytelling with Tableau
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course
courses.required_readings:
Shelly Cashman Series® Microsoft® Office 365 & Excel 2016: Comprehensive, Cengage.
Mary Anne Poatsy, Exploring Microsoft Office Excel 2016 Comprehensive, Pearson.
courses.recommended_readings:
Tableau Starter Kits: https://www.tableau.com/learn/starter-kits
Tableau Free Training Videos: https://www.tableau.com/learn/training

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Basic Quantitative Methods for Hospitality and Real Estate
courses.description: This course introduces statistical and operation methods appropriate to the hospitality and real estate industry, which include descriptive statistics, probability, correlation and regression, forecasting, decision analysis, quality control, and hotel yield management. Each method will be discussed using examples related to the hospitality and real estate industry.
courses.learning_outcomes: This course aims to introduce basic statistical and other analytical tools and concepts that are applicable to decision-making in various business settings. Emphases are on the understanding and application of these concepts. Students are expected to develop their ability to learn independently, and to learn/operate in a group environment. The instructor's role is to organize the learning materials, establish the macro framework of the learning materials/concepts so as to illustrate "the big picture", point out areas of emphasis and alternative considerations, motivate your learning, assist in your understanding of the materials, and assess your learning outcome.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction: Data and Descriptive Measures Basic
• Probability and Discrete Probability Distribution
• The Normal Distribution
• Sampling Distributions
• Confidence Interval Estimation
• Fundamentals of Hypothesis Testing: One-Sample Tests
• Two-Sample Tests with Numerical Data
• Test of Proportions
• Tests for Two or More Samples with Categorical Data
• Simple Correlation & Linear Regression
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings: Berenson, Levine, and Krehbiel, Basic Business Statistics – Concepts and Applications, Prentice Hall, (International Edition).
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Economics for Business Studies I
courses.description: This course is a general introduction to the theory of price in a market economy. Topics include basic economic concepts, the theory of demand, production and cost, the operation of firms in competitive, oligopolistic and monopolistic markets, costs and benefits of government intervention in market economy, and introduction to game theory and informational economics. Analytical approach is used whenever appropriate. Applications on practical business problems are emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ECON2011 or ECON3011.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to understand, explain and identify the followings:

(1) Basic concepts of scarcity, opportunity cost, demand and supply mechanisms and their applications to the business world.
(2) The factors that determine the market demand and their effects by the concept of elasticity.
(3) The factors that determine the market supply, the relationship between production function and costs of production.
(4) The different market structures (i.e., perfect competition, monopoly and oligopoly) and relate them to the conduct of a firm and performance of the industry.
(5) The market failure and their remedies.
courses.course_syllabus: This course is a general introduction to the theory of price in a market economy. Topics include basic economic concepts, the theory of demand, production and cost, the operation of firms in competitive, oligopolistic and monopolistic markets, costs and benefits of government intervention in market economy, and introductory issues to game theory and information economics. Analytical approach is used whenever appropriate. Applications on practical business problems are emphasized.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Teachers get feedback from CTE. Other methods such as focus group meeting, mid-term evaluation, questionnaire, online survey and discussion may be used as well.

courses.recommended_readings:

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Basic Economics for the Hospitality and Tourism Industry
courses.description: This course is to provide the students with a basic understanding of the economics of the firm as well as macro-economics. The market forces of demand and supply as well as the firm's price and output decision under various forms of market structure will be analysed. In addition, national income, international trade theory, commercial policies, and foreign exchange market will be treated briefly. Economic applications that are particularly relevant to the hospitality industry will be emphasized.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
• Develop a basic understanding of demand, supply and elasticity
• Explain the basics of the costs of production and market structure
• Explain the basics of national income accounting.
• Develop a basic understanding of the determinants of economic growth.
• Explain the determination of saving, investment and the interest rate in the market.
• Explain what money is and what the functions of money are.
• Examine the banking system and the money creation process.
• Distinguish between expected inflation and unexpected inflation and
• Describe the real effects of inflation.
• Explain the basic model of aggregate demand and aggregate supply.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Supply and demand
• Elasticity
• Efficiency and costs of taxation
• Government policies
• Costs of production
• Competitive market
• Public goods
• The money sector
• The real sector
• Monetary and Fiscal Policies
• Short-run economic trade-off
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings: Textbook: Mankiw, N. G. Principles of Economics, Thomson South-Western.
courses.recommended_readings:
Bernanke, B., Frank, R. Principles of Economics, McGraw-Hill Irwin.
Bade and Parkin, Foundations of Macroeconomics, Addison Wesley.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Fundamentals of Business Economics
courses.description: This course intends to provide students with fundamentals to the understandings of both micro- and macro-economics for business decision makings and applications. Topics of microeconomics include demand and supply and elasticities, market structure and monopoly power, and the government and its economic functions. Topics of macroeconomics include unemployment, inflation, GDP and long term growth issues, aggregate supply and demand, and fiscal and monetary policies. Other topics of interests can also be included by the course instructor.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken DSME1030/DOTE1030, DSME1040/DOTE1040 and equivalent courses offered by other departments.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to understand, explain and apply:
(1) Basic concepts of scarcity, opportunity cost, demand and supply mechanisms, elasticity, and their applications to the business world.
(2) Different market structures such as perfect competition and monopoly.
(3) The concept of market failure and their remedies.
(4) Key macroeconomic variables such as gross domestic product (GDP), consumer price index (CPI), unemployment rate, and economic growth.
(5) The concepts of aggregate supply (AS), aggregate demand (AD), and the use of fiscal and monetary policies.
courses.course_syllabus: This course provides students with fundamentals to the understandings of both micro- and macro-economics for business decision makings and applications. Topics of Microeconomics include demand and supply and elasticities, market structure and monopoly power, and the government and its economic functions. Topics of Macroeconomics include unemployment, inflation, GDP and long term growth issues, aggregate supply and demand, and fiscal and monetary policies.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Economics for Business Studies II
courses.description: This course is a general introduction to the theory of the determination of national income and aggregate economic behaviour. Topics include national income accounting, unemployment, inflation, monetary and fiscal policies for economic stabilization, and international economic issues. Applications of basic macroeconomic principles to contemporary business issues are emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ECON2021 or ECON3021 or UGEC2015
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to understand, explain and apply:
(1) Economic variables such as gross national product (GNP), gross domestic product (GDP), consumer price index (CPI), unemployment rate, and economic growth rate.
(2) Economic models that explain the business cycles.
(3) The role of banking sector, the creation of money, the role of central bank and its impact on monetary policy.
(4) The long-run and short-run aggregate supply (AS) and aggregate demand (AD).
(5) The role of government and effects of fiscal policy.
(6) The international economy in the context of foreign exchanges and balance of payments (BOP).
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is a general introduction to the theory of the determination of national income and aggregate economic behavior. Topics include national income accounting, unemployment theory, inflation, monetary & fiscal policies for economics stabilization, and international economic issues. Applications of basic macroeconomic principles to contemporary business issues are emphasized.

Course Outline
• Measuring a Nation's Income
• Measuring the Cost of Living
• Production and Growth
• Saving, Investment and the Financial System
• The Basic Tools of Finance
• Unemployment
• The Monetary System
• Money Growth and Inflation
• Aggregate Demand (AD) and Aggregate Supply (AS)
• The Influence of Monetary and Fiscal Policy on AD
• The Short-run Tradeoff between Inflation and Unemployment
• Open-Economy Macroeconomics: Basic Concepts
• A Macroeconomic Theory of the Open Economy
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE and discussion with students outside the classroom.
courses.required_readings: N. Gregory Mankiw, Principles of Macroeconomics, South-Western.
courses.recommended_readings: Bade and Parkin, Foundations of Macroeconomics, Addison Wesley.

courses.description: This course introduces to students selected topics in applied statistics which are useful to business decisions and research. Regression analysis is stressed. Topics include linear regression models, some special topics in regression analysis and two-factor analysis of variance (ANOVA). Applications to business and economic problems will be emphasized throughout this course.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Operations Management

meetings.location: Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall1
Fung King Hey Bldg Swire Hall1

courses.description: The objective of this course is to provide students with an understanding of how the design, operation, and control of production/operation systems can most effectively produce and/or deliver goods and services to meet customers' needs. Students will be exposed to the problems and issues confronting operations managers in the business world today. Students will also be provided with the language, concepts, insights and tools to address operations management issues. How companies can gain competitive advantage through operations will be discussed. This course will emphasize applications rather than theories. However, the underlying logic of the concepts will be examined so that students can understand the principles upon which their approach is based.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: HTMG1010 or MGNT1010 or 1020.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Operations Strategy and Competitiveness
• Process Management (Types of Processes, Manufacturing Processes vs. Service Processes, etc.)
• Project management
• Quality Management (Six Sigma, etc.)
• Inventory Management (EOQ, Safety Stock, etc.)
• Distribution, Logistics, and ERP system
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term

courses.recommended_readings:

3. Krajewski, Ritzman, Operations Management, processes and Value Chains, Pearson Prentice Hall.
4. Keizer, Render, Operations Management, Pearson International Edition.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Analytics
courses.description: This course will provide a basis for handling and analyzing business data. This course will also give a chance to learn R which is rapidly becoming the default analytics platform as it supports diverse set of analytic tools and statistical methods. This course will present students with real datasets and give opportunities of ‘learning by doing’ through hands-on experience. Specifically, we will study basic concepts in business analytics, and techniques and skills related to data exploration, data utilities, conducting statistical tests, data mining and modeling.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are able to perform the followings using R programming:
(1) To summarize and visualize business data
(2) To conduct basic statistical tests
(3) To find meaningful association between variables
(4) To classify users based on their revealed preference
(5) To build various empirical models and estimate the parameters
(6) To apply skills acquired from their hands-on practices to other business cases
courses.course_syllabus:
• Analytics Basics
- Value of Business Analytics
- Correlation and Causality

• Data Exploration
- R Basics and Data Utilities
- Summarize and Visualize Data
- Data Description for Datasets 1
- Generate New Variables
- Basic statistical tests
- Data Description for Datasets 2
- ANOVA/MANOVA/ANCOVA
- Data Description for Datasets 3

• Data Mining
- Association Model
- Classification Model
- Clustering Model

• Regression Models
- Regression Model I
- Regression Model II
- Panel Model
- Survival Model

• Wrap-Up
- Addressing Endogeneity
- Final Exam
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings:

Kabacoff, R in Action: Data Analysis and Graphics with R.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Information Systems
courses.description: This course aims to survey information system technology with an emphasis on the development of computer-based information systems (CBIS). Major topics include: impact of CBIS on management, elements of system development life cycle, data management, transaction processing system, decision support systems, expert systems, and information resources management, etc. Important issues in e-Business such as information technology, security, marketing, finance, and multi-national trade, and practical operation will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Prerequisite: ACCT1111 or 2111 or HTMG1010 or MGNT1010 or 1020.
2. Not for students who have taken SEEM3490.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are able to:
(1) Understand the basic concepts of information systems and e-commerce.
(2) Understand the value of CBIS in business and organization.
(3) Know how to manage data from both external (e.g. business partners) and internal (e.g. functional units) sources.
(4) Derive logical design of business applications by using the modeling tools such as ER diagram, Data Flow Diagram, Decision Tree, and Decision Table.
(5) Apply practical IT skills acquired from their hands-on projects or cases.
(6) Improve their presentation skill and communication skill.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces the conceptual foundations of information systems (IS). The technical aspect of IS and their relevance to business functions will also be covered. We will also examine how IS can be applied to support business operations in organizations. Important topics covered include:
(1) The fundamentals of computer based information systems(CBIS)
(2) Types of business information systems such as decision support systems, expert systems and enterprise resources systems
(3) Telecommunications and networks, including the Internet, intranets, and extranets
(4) Database management and business intelligence
(5) System development life cycle
(6) e-Business and mobile business
(7) Hands-on training on spreadsheet, database, and web software
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings:
R. Kelly Rainer, Efraim Turban/ John Wiley & Sons, Inc., Introduction to Information Systems: Supporting and Transforming Business.

Ralph M. Stair and George W. Reynolds, Principles of Information Systems, Course Technology.

Simha R. Magal and Jeffrey Word, Essentials of Business Processes and Information Systems, Wiley.
courses.recommended_readings:

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Artificial Intelligence Empowered Business

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description: In today’s fast-evolving digital landscape, artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming how businesses operate, innovate, and compete. This course provides business undergraduate students with a comprehensive understanding of AI concepts, tools and applications in the business world. Through case studies, hands-on projects and interactive discussions, students will explore topics such as machine learning, data-driven decision-making, AI ethics and industry-specific applications. By the end of the course, students will be equipped with the knowledge and skills to leverage AI for strategic advantage and drive innovation in their future careers.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DOTE1021 or DOTE2011 or ECON2121 or FINA2230 or STAT2001 or permission from instructor
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand fundamental AI concepts and terminology, including machine learning, neural networks, and data science.
2. Identify what AI can and cannot realistically achieve in business settings.
3. Spot opportunities to apply AI to solve organizational challenges.
4. Gain hands-on experience with different AI tools to explore data science and machine learning projects.
5. Navigate ethical, legal, and societal discussions surrounding AI adoption.
courses.course_syllabus:
13-Week Course Schedule

Week 1: Introduction to AI and Its Role in Business

* Overview of AI: What it is and why it matters
* History and evoluction of AI in technoloty and business
* Current trends and future potential of AI
* In-class activity: Discussion on examples of AI in everyday business

Week 2: Key Concepts in AI

* Fundamentals of machine learning, neural networks, and deep learning
* Differences between AI, machine learning, and data science
* Types of machine learning: Suprevised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning
* Case studies: How companies use machine learning for strategic advantage

Week 3: Data Science Foundations for AI

* Data collection, preprocessing, and visualization
* Introduction to tools: Excel, Python, or R for basic data analysis
* Hands-on-practice: Cleaning and exploring datasets
* Discussion: The importance of data quality in AI success

Week 4: AI Applications in Difference Industries

* AI in marketing: Predictive and analytics, personlization, and chatbots
* AI in finance: Fraud detection and algorithmic trading
* AI in supply chain management and operations
* Group activity: Brainstorming industry-specific AI use cases

Week 5: Identifying AI Opportunities in Business

* Framework for spotting opportunities to apply AI
* Understanding business pain points and matching them with AI solutions
* Case study: Companies that succeeded or failed with AI adoption
* In-class workshop: Identifying potential AI applications in a chosen business

Week 6: Building Simple AI Models

* Introduction to AI tools and platforms (e.g., Google Colab, Cursor, Tableau, RapidMiner, etc.)
* Hands-on session: Building a basic predictive model using machine learning
* Interpreting model outputs and understanding their business implications
* Discussion: Challenges in deploying AI solutions

Week 7: Advance Topics in AI

* Introduction to natural language processing (NLP) and computer vision (CV)
* Generative AI: Opportunities and risks in content creation
* Case studies: Examples of NLP and generative AI in business
* Hands-on session: Experimenting with a generative AI tool (e,g, ChagGPT)

Week 8: Designing AI-Driven Strategies

* Strategic planning with AI: Aligning AI initiatives with business goals
* Developing AI roadmaps for organizations
* Group activity: Drafting an AI implementation strategy for a sample business
* Peer feedback session: Sharing and refining strategies

Week 9: Ethics, Bias, and Governance in AI

* Ethical dilemmas in AI (e.g., bias in algorithms, privacy concerns)
* Legal and regulatory frameworks for AI (global and regional)
* Discussion: How companies can ensure responsible AI usage
* Group activity: Debating the ethics of AI in controversial scenarios

Week 10: AI Limitations and Challenges

* The limitations of AI: What it can and cannot do
* Common pitfalls in AI implementation (e.g., lack of data, over-reliance on AI)
* Misconceptions about AI in business
* Guest lecture: Practitioner discussing real-world challenges with AI

Week 11: Societal Impact of AI

* AI's impact on jobs, labor market, automation, and the workforce
* Economic implications of AI adoption
* In-class debate: Does AI create more opportunities or challenges for society
* Reflection: Balancing innovation with inclusivity and fairness

Week 12: Capstone Project Development

* Finalizing group capstone projects: Identifying a business challenge and proposing AI solutions
* Group work: Refining presentations and preparing deliverables
* Instructor and peer feedback sessions to improvie final projects
* Tips on presenting business-oriented AI solutions effectively

Week 13: Capstone Project Presentations and Wrap-Up

* Group presentations: Proposing AI solutions to address specific business challenges
* Peer evaluations and instructor feedback on presentations
* Reflection on key lessons learned during the course
* Course wrap-up: Review of AI trends and future opportunities
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings:
All the course materials will be distributed via GitHub.

1. Cases, technical blogs and relevant online articles as required readings
2. Jupyter Notebooks for the code and implementation details of the technical content
3. Access to online AI tools and platforms such as Google CoLab, Cursor, and Rapid/Miner
courses.recommended_readings: Supplementary readings and cases provided weekly

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Behavioral Economics and Business Decisions
courses.description: Building on booming evidence in psychology and economics suggesting that individuals' behaviors deviate from the standard economic theory systematically, behavioral economics becomes a fast growing field. In this course, we will provide a broad overview of the modern advances in behavioral economics and the insights gained from incorporating psychology into economic modeling to understand how the psychological factors affect individuals' decision making, and show the business implications of those psychologically richer models, specifically on the strategies of areas including but not limited to consumer decision, investment and competition strategy of the firm, pricing practice, management decision, marketing and advertising, finance and insurance market.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030 or equivalent course
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Introduction and The Fundamentals of Behavioral Economics
• From Homo Economicus to Homo Sapiens
• Rationality and Irrational Behaviors
• Some Facts in Psychology
(2) Reference-dependence and Loss-Aversion
• Endowment Effect and Applications: Housing Market, Labor Supply and Finance
• Mental Accounting Theory and Sunk Cost Effect
• Loss-Aversion and Equity Premium Puzzle
(3) Preferences over Risk and Uncertainty
• Expected and Non-expected Utility Theory
• Ellsberg Paradox and Allais Paradox
• Prospect Theory and Applications: Finance, Labor Supply, Consumer Behavior and Insurance
(4) Time-inconsistency and Self-Control
• Time-Inconsistent Preferences and The Multi-Selves Approach
• Beta-Delta Framework and Applications: Self-Control Problem
• Imperfect Will-Power and Material Foundations
(5) Social Preferences
• Social Preference Theories
• Lab and Field Evidence: Charity, Cooperation and Reciprocity
(6) Behavioral Game Theory and Experiment
• Theory and Experiment of Strategic Interaction
• Game Theory with Bounded Rationality
(7) Other Topics in Behavioral Economics
• Other Topics and Advances in Behavioral Economics
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course
courses.required_readings: Camerer C., G. Loewenstein and M. Rabin. Advances in Behavioral Economics, Princeton University Press
courses.recommended_readings:
Ariely, D. Predictably Irrational: The Hidden Forces That Shape Our Decisions, Harper Collins.
Baumeister, R. and J. Tierney. Willpower: Why Self-Control is the Secret to Success, Penguin Books.
Blundell, Whitney K. Newey, and Torsten Persson, eds., Cambridge and New York: Cambridge University Press.
Camerer, C. "Behavioral Economics," in Advances in Economics and Econometrics: Theory and Applications, Ninth World Congress, Volume 2, Richard Blundell, Whitney Newey, and Torsten Persson (Cambridge University Press), 181-214.
Kahneman, D. Thinking, Fast and Slow, Penguin Books.
Rubinstein, A. Modeling Bounded Rationality, MIT Press.
Thaler, R. The Winner's Curse: Paradoxes and Anomalies of Economic Life, Princeton University Press.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Forecasting
courses.description: This course provides students with principles and methods in forecasting for managerial planning. Major topics include multiple regression analysis and time series analysis with emphasis on smoothing techniques, decomposition methods, Box-Jenkins procedures, and indicator forecasting. Applications of the methods to both short-term and long-term forecasting to business, industries and national business trends are also emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: DSME2011/DOTE2011 and DSME2021/DOTE2021.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) Understand and use the following forecasting methods: multiple regression analysis, time series analysis (with emphasis on smoothing techniques), decomposition methods, Box-Jenkins procedures, and indicator forecasting
(2) Apply the above forecast methods to both short-term and long-term forecasting in business, industries, and national business trends
(3) Use various statistical software to perform forecast
courses.course_syllabus:
• An Introduction to Forecasting
• Basic Statistical Concepts
• Simple Linear Regression
• Multiple Linear Regression
• Model Building and Residual Analysis
• Time Series Regression
• Decomposition Methods
• Exponential Smoothing
• Nonseasonal Box-Jenkins Models and their Tentative Identification
• Estimation, Diagnostic Checking, and Forecasting for Nonseasonal Box-Jenkins Models
• Box-Jenkins Seasonal Modeling
• Advanced Box-Jenkins Modeling
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Corporate Economics
courses.description: This course provides economic views on the operations of enterprises in a market environment for corporate decision-making and strategy formulation. Students will learn how to analyse market structure and performance, how firms seek competitive advantage, and how industries change. Emphasis will be on the application of economic principles to major business decisions, including pricing, product mix, market entry, mergers, and adoption of new technologies. Industrial policy and its implications will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: (a) DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040 and (b) HTMG1010 or MGNT1020
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) Will be able to demonstrate understanding of what corporate strategies are
(2) Use economic theory to analyze issues in strategic management under different market structures
(3) Appreciate the importance of corporate strategic decisions
(4) Evaluate the role of game theoretic approaches to strategic choices
(5) Understand the challenges and opportunities of a firm under globalizations
courses.course_syllabus:
The overall aim of the course is to provide you with an understanding of strategic decisions in firms, and the contribution of economic principles to the analysis and formulation of corporate strategy. The course is linked to the theory of the firm, industrial organization and strategy research and application of game theory to corporate decisions making. In particular, we will emphasize on practical applications of topics from industrial economics and strategy to the real world. Finally, we will emphasize on the current macroeconomic and capital market environments to contemporary corporate decisions making.

Course Outline:
• Basic: Microeconomic Principles
• Economics of Scale and Scope
• Agency and Coordination
• The Vertical Boundaries of the firm
• Organizing Vertical Boundaries: Vertical
Integration and Its Alternatives
• Diversification
• Competitors and Competition
• Strategic Commitment
• The Dynamic of Pricing Rivalry
• Entry and Exit
• Industry Analysis
• Strategic Positioning for Competitive Advantage
• Current Topic in Corporate Economics
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE and discussion with students outside classroom.
courses.required_readings: D. Besanko, D. Dranove, M. Shanley and S. Schaefer (BDSS), Economics of Strategy, John Wiley & Sons.
courses.recommended_readings:
Baye, Michael, Managerial Economics and Business Strategy, McGraw Hill.
Spulber, Daniel, Economics and Management of Competitive Strategy, World Scientific.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Global Economics
courses.description:
The purpose of this course is to equip business students with theory and knowledge of international economics. Both international trade and international macroeconomics will be covered. Applications, especially to current issues, will be emphasized throughout the course.
Topics are categorized into three parts: international trade theory and policy, international macroeconomic theory and practice, and applications such as the impact of globalization, and the linked exchange rate in Hong Kong.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part 1. International Trade Theory and Policy (Weeks 1-4)
• Labor Productivity and Comparative Advantage: The Ricardian Model
• Specific Factors and Income Distribution
• The Instruments of Trade Policy
Part 2. International Macroeconomic Theory and Practice (Weeks 5-9)
• Exchange Rates and the Foreign Exchange Market
• Money, Interest Rates, and Exchange Rates
• Price Levels and the Exchange Rate in the Long Run
• Output and the Exchange Rate in the Short Run
Part 3. Applications and Current International Issues (Weeks 10-12)
• Optimum Currency Areas and the European Experience
• Developing Countries: Growth, Crisis, and Reform
Part 4. Project Presentation (Weeks 13-14)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and teaching evaluation
courses.required_readings: Krugman, Paul R., Maurice Obstfeld, and Marc Melitz, International Economics: Theory and Policy, Addison-Wesley.
courses.recommended_readings:
Caves, Richard E., Frankel, Jeffrey, A., and Ronald W. Jones, World Trade and Payments: An Introduction, Addison-Wesley.
Appleyard, Dennis, R., Alfred J. Field, Jr., and Steven Cobb, International Economics, McGraw-Hill.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Economic Aspects of Business Environment
courses.description: This course provides students with an economic perspective of the business environment and equips them with a solid grounding in business economics required for management studies at the university level. The major topics include: economic views of government and business; public choice and regulation; fiscal, monetary, trade and development policies; and the international environment. Examples will be drawn from Hong Kong, PRC in its economic reform since 1979 and the Asian NIE's competitive advantage and trade and industrial policy. Students are expected to exercise initiative in identifying aspects of special interest for in-depth reading. Empirical aspects of economic studies will be stressed through lecturing and case study.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040, or equivalent courses.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students would learn about (a) Hong Kong's banking system and its changes over the decade, (b) Hong Kong's currency board system, and (c) Hong Kong as an international financial centre, the last two with a comparative perspective.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Hong Kong's banking system in the first decades.
• Establishment of Hong Kong's monetary system.
• The current Hong Kong dollar link: operations, performance, and effects.
• The future of the Hong Kong dollar link.
• Hong Kong as an international financial centre.
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by the end of the term
courses.required_readings:
Instructor's Notes

John G. Greenwood, "Hong Kong's Financial Crisis", Asian Monetary Monitor, Vol. 6, No. 6, pp. 1-69. Reprinted in John Greenwood, Hong Kong's Link to the US Dollar: Origins and Evolution, Hong Kong: Hong Kong University Press, pp 51-99.

Richard Roberts, The City: A Guide to London's Global Financial Centre, Second Edition, London: The Economist in association with Profile Books Ltd, Selections.
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Macroeconomics for Managers
courses.description: This intermediate-level macroeconomics course is application-oriented and aimed at potential managers. Topics include contemporary aggregate demand and aggregate supply models; money and banking; fiscal and monetary policies on the macro economy and business environments; models of investments; real versus financial investments and evaluation; business cycle theory and sectorial forecasts; and the international linkage and different exchange rate systems. Managerial strategies to the changing business and macroeconomic environments will be emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040, or equivalent courses.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students would learn the fixed exchange rate version of the Mundell-Fleming model as well as Hong Kong’s economic institution.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Basic measures of the macroeconomy.
• Hong Kong's Trends and Business Cycles.
• Growth.
• The IS-LM model.
• The Balance of Payments and exchange rates.
• The Mundell-Fleming Model.
• The AD-AS Model.
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Game Theory for Business Strategy
courses.description: This course aims to develop a game theoretic framework for understanding strategies in business. When making managerial decisions, managers must take into account the reactions of rival firms, governments and their subordinates. Game theory offers a systematic way to analyze strategic decision-making process in business, including competition in oligopoly market, contract design, strategic use of information, auction and bargaining.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030
courses.course_syllabus:
• The Nature of Strategic Interaction
• Games with Sequential Moves
• Games with Simultaneous Moves
• Simultaneous-Move Games with Mixed Strategies
• Commitment and Strategic Moves: R&D and Price War
• Prisoners’Dilemma and Repetition: Choice of Product Mix
• Issues in Auctions
• Bargaining
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and teaching evaluation
courses.required_readings: Dixit, Skeath, and Reiley, Games of Strategy, 3e, W. W. Norton & Company.
courses.recommended_readings:
Osborne, An introduction to game theory, Oxford University Press.
McMillan, Games, Strategies, and Managers, Oxford University Press.
Webster, Introduction to Game Theory in Business and Economics.
Gardner, Games for Business and Economics.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Decision Modeling and Analytics
courses.description: This course introduces the concepts and methods of decision making and analysis, which involves the application of mathematical modeling and analysis to business problems. Models are simplified representations of real situations and can be invaluable tools in decision making. Students will learn the basic elements of modeling-how to formulate a model and how to use and interpret the information a model produces. The emphasis is on models that are widely used in diverse industries and functional areas, including finance, operations, and marketing. Applications include production planning, revenue management, sales force planning, risk management, portfolio optimization, among others. We use spreadsheets and other tools to implement, solve, and analyze the models we develop.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction to Spreadsheet Modeling and Problem Solving
- Spreadsheet Engineering and Analysis
- Modeling and Prototyping
- Modeling in Practice
- Introduction to Optimization and Solver
- Optimization Models and Sensitivity Analysis
- Production Planning, Revenue Management, and Sales Force Sizing and Allocation
- Simulation Techniques and Examples
- Simulation Modeling and Analysis
- Managing Risk with Insurance
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings: Management Science: The Art of Modeling with Spreadsheets, by Stephen G. Powell, Kenneth R. Baker
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Web Analytics
courses.description: The course focuses on the collection, analysis, and reporting of Internet data for purposes of optimizing web usage and enhancing business decisions. Both online and offline web analytics tools are used for measuring and analyzing web traffic, website performance, and visitor behavior in online commercial settings. Topics covered include web analytics concepts, web analytics technologies and techniques, visitor activity analysis methods, and web intelligence fundamentals.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: DSME2011/DOTE2011 and DSME2021/DOTE2021 or permission of instructor.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Fundamentals of web analytics
- Big data and small data: different types of intelligence
- Website success measures: site goals, key performance indicators, and key metrics
- Tools and techniques of Web analytics: focus on learning the use of Google Analytics
- Website performance analysis: traffic analysis and search and keyword analysis
- Using visitor data to drive website improvement
- Leveraging digital analytics effectively
- Emerging analytics: social, mobile, and video
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
Clifton, B. Advanced Metrics with Google Analytics, Wiley Publishing, Inc.

Isson, J-P. and Harriot, J. Win with Advanced Business Analytics: Creating Business Values from Your Data, Wiley and SAS.

Kaushik, A. Web Analytics 2.0, Wiley Publishing, Inc.

Russell, M.A. Mining the Social Web: Analyzing Data from Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and Other Social Media Sites. O’Reilly Meida, Inc.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Managerial Economics in the Information Age
courses.description: Managerial Economics combines economic theory and managerial practice, and it is the economic foundation of business analysis and strategy. This course focuses on the application of economic theories and tools to real world management problems and business challenges. Drawing on decision theory, game theory, models of markets and quantitative techniques, the course will apply fundamental concepts of economics to various business decisions, such as demand analysis, production and cost, pricing practices, capital budgeting and risk analysis. Particular attention will be paid to new industries in the information age.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040.
courses.course_syllabus:
• The fundamentals of managerial economics
• Market forces: demand and supply & quantitative demand analysis
• Managing firms in competitive, monopolistic, and monopolistically competitive market
• Game theory and oligopoly models
• Pricing strategies
• The economics of information
• Capital budgeting and investment under uncertainty
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by the end of the term
courses.required_readings: Michael Baye, Managerial Economics and Business Strategy, McGraw Hill.
courses.recommended_readings:
Dennis W. Carlton & Jeffrey M. Perloff, Modern Industrial Organization, Pearson Education.

Ivan Png, Managerial Economics, Asian Pacific Edition, Pearson Education South Asian Pte Ltd.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Management and Big Data Analytics
courses.description: This course focuses on (1) business data requirement analysis, modeling and management; and (2) big data crawling, management system and analytics. The main theme is to capture business applications and requirements, turn them into data models and manage the data using modern database systems. We will also examine methods for capturing, organizing and manipulating big data. Topics such as data integration, big data, DBMS, SQL, Relational model, Entity Relationship model, Data Warehousing, MongoDB, NoSQL and Map/Reduce are covered.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The role of database systems has extended from being key computing facilities supporting information management into key information resources enabling enterprises to compete in the global marketplace. Modern information technology is now available to facilitate knowledge creation out of existing data sources, codify and store knowledge for subsequent sharing and applications that create value. This course studies the basic methods, models and techniques of data and knowledge management. Specifically, it will achieve the following goals:

1. Discuss database design, processing, and management in the context of relational systems. Topics such as normalization, integrity controls, and query languages (SQL) are emphasized.
2. Develop competence in data modeling. Entity-Relationship models and other semantic data modeling methods are studied and their use for database design is illustrated.
3. Gain hands-on experiences with database systems development using CASE tool and RDBMS.
4. Cover knowledge acquisition, representation and applying knowledge through expert system.
5. Introduce business intelligent that involves discovery knowledge from disparate data sources. Data warehouse, OLAP, data mining and big data are studied.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Database Introductions
- The concept of data integration and the database approach
- Basic file structures in database systems

Part II: Data Modeling
- Relational data model & Normalization schema, integrity rules and implementation
- Structured Query Language
- Semantic data modeling Entity, Relationship and Attributes

Part III: Database Processing and Implementation
- Enterprise modeling: an integrated view using Subject, Context, Entity, and Relationship (Demonstration of a CASE software, IBMS)
- Databases and the Internet ODBC, OLE DB, ADO, & ASP
- Transaction Management, Concurrence Control, and Distributed Database

Part IV: Business Intelligence
- Data Warehousing & Big Data
- Data mining

Part V: Knowledge Based System
- Knowledge acquisition, representation, & reasoning
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings: Carlos C., S. Morris, P. Rob, Database Principles: Fundamentals of Design, Implementation and Management, Thomson Publishing Company.
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Guided Research in Business Economics
courses.description: The course allows students to investigate in depth a topic of business economics issues under close direction of a teacher. The topics include important macroeconomic issues and policies related to business operation, economy industry analysis, corporate strategies and trend forecasting in a particular industry, and governmental industrial policies and regulations. The course also covers essential skills in research, report writing and presentation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040.
courses.course_syllabus:
- General principle in research methodologies
- Selected topics in business economics
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course and teaching evaluation
Focus group
courses.required_readings: Don Ethridge. Research Methodology in Applied Economics, Blackwell Publishing.
courses.recommended_readings:
Blaug, Mark. The Methodology of Economics or How Economists Explain.
Cambridge University Press.
Sectoral Analysis, Research Guide, UCLA Library
(http://guides.library.ucla.edu/SectorAnalysis)
Workings papers and research reports from International Monetary Fund (IMF), World Bank, World Trade Organization (WTO) etc.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Economic Analytics

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04

courses.description: This course aims to provide economic views on the operations of enterprises for understanding corporate decision making and strategy formulation. The course is linked to game theory, the theory of the firm and industrial organization, and information economics. In particular, emphasis will be placed on the application of economic principles to major business decisions, including pricing, market entry and exit, strategic use of information and contract design. Industry analysis and governmental regulation will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030
courses.course_syllabus:
• Game Theoretic Analysis
• Competition in Oligopoly Market
• Firm Boundaries
• Entry and Exit
• Asymmetric Information: Screening and Signaling
• Contract Design: Principal-Agent Problem and Incentive Alignment
• Industry Analysis

courses.recommended_readings:

Perloff, Microeconomics, Pearson Prentice Hall.
Dixit, Skeath, and Reiley, Games of Strategy, W. W. Norton & Company.
Osborne, An introduction to game theory, Oxford University Press.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Selected Topics of Decisions, Operations and Technology
courses.description: This course is designed to investigate and to discuss selected topics of current interests in the area of business/managerial economic and/or decision science analysis.
courses.learning_outcomes: Learning objectives are set in accordance to the topics selected and will take reference to the corresponding programme learning goals.
courses.course_syllabus: To be designed by course teacher.
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Information Systems Analysis and Design
courses.description: This course aims to introduce to students various activities associated with the development of business information systems. Students will learn to analyse information requirements and to design appropriate solutions that lead to sophisticated business systems. The concepts of system development life cycle (SDLC) and human- computer interaction will be introduced. Various methodologies, such as structured- and object-oriented analysis and design, will be emphasized. An introduction on how to use a CASE tool to help developing business information systems will also be given.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME2051/DOTE2051 or permission of instructor.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to business IS development life cycle
• Information system planning
• Analysis and design models using structural approach
• Object Modeling using Unified Modeling Language (UML)
• Major components in IS testing
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term

(2) Fowler, M. UML Distilled. - A Brief Guide to the Standard Object Modeling Language, Addison-Wesley.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Communications and Networking
courses.description: This course introduces data communications concepts, components, architecture, protocols, and standards for message movement within a network. Both the technical and managerial aspects of designing, controlling, and managing networks in the distributed environment will be emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME2051/DOTE2051 or permission of instructor.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction
• Business Information

Data Communication Fundamentals
• Transmission and Media
• Communications Fundamentals
• Transmission Efficiency

Local Area Networks
• LAN Technologies and Systems
• Wireless Local Area Networks

Wide Area Networks
• Circuit/Packet Switching
• Frame Relay and ATM
• Wireless Wide Area Network

Internet
• History and Architecture
• TCP/IP and OSI
• Client/Server and Intranet

Network Management Issues

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Financial Information Technology
courses.description: This course examines the use of information technology and systems in financial services and investment management. Topics covered include neural network, fuzzy logic, data mining and decision technologies relevant to financial services. Students will also learn to use Excel VBA to develop financial application systems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: DSME2051/DOTE2051 or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. understand the roles and impacts of IT and EC on financial services
2. apply IT in analyzing and solving financial problems
3. become skilful at Excel VBA
4. use Excel VBA in evaluating financial investments, including bonds and stocks
5. adopt EC and its technologies in improving organizational performance
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics covered include:
• IT application in financial sector
• IT technologies and management in financial sector
• Ecommerce application in financial sector
• Ecommerce technologies and management in financial sector
• Development of financial applications using Excel and VBA
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students can provide feedback anytime using email, phone, or office visit.
courses.required_readings: There is no textbook for this course. However, students have assigned readings from the reference list. Lecture notes are also available in CUHK's Blackboard.
courses.recommended_readings:

2. Fan, Srinivasan, Stallaert, and Whinston (FSSW), Electronic commerce and the revolution in financial markets, South-western Thomas Learning.
3. Giarratano and Riley. Expert Systems: Principles and programming, Thomson Course Technology.
4. Bodie, Kane, and Marcus (BKM). Investments, McGraw-Hill.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Global Logistics Management
courses.description: This course will examine the integrative role of logistics within the supply chain and look at logistics services from the perspective of logistic service providers. The general concepts and importance of global logistics management will be a major focus. We will provide students with an overall understanding of various activities handled by logistic service providers. Through problem-solving scenarios, projects and case studies, we will cover concepts, practical tools, and effective practices in logistics management. Topics include: introduction to the logistics functions and logistics industries, distribution strategies, warehousing and transportation management, design of the logistics networks, purchasing and outsourcing, and logistics information systems.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) Understand the economic impacts of logistics
(2) Learn the importance of supply chain management
(3) Know the elements of logistics system
(4) Interact with logistics professionals or specialists using language used in logistics industry
(5) Develop skills and ability to solve logistics management problems.
courses.course_syllabus:
Review of Basic Concepts in Logistics
• Overview of Logistics
• Supply Chain Management
• Elements of Logistics Systems
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings: Contemporary Logistics, Murphy and Wood, latest edition, Pearson
courses.recommended_readings:
Chase, Jacobs, Aquilano, Operations Management for Competitive Advantage, Latest Edition, McGraw-Hill Irwin

Simchi-Levi, David; Kaminsky, Philip; Simchi-Levi, Edith, Designing and Managing the Supply Chain - Concepts, Strategies and Case Studies, latest edition, McGraw-Hill.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Global Supply Chain Management
courses.description: This course will examine the strategic role of supply chain management in global competition. We provide students with the concepts, decision models and practical tools necessary for effective decision-making in the various areas of supply chain. Through problem solving and case studies, the course will develop students’ intuition behind many key supply chain concepts and practices. We will demonstrate how cost reduction, productivity improvement, flexibility, speed, and customer satisfaction can be achieved through supply chain enhancement. Topics include: the strategic framework for supply chain management, planning the demand and supply in a supply chain, planning and managing inventories in a supply chain, information technology management and information sharing in a supply chain, strategic alliances and coordination.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Understand the roles that supply chains play in a global economy. You will understand how supply chain work and contribute to the success of the firm.
2. Understand the goals and objectives of supply chain management. We will discuss key decisions and trade-offs involved in effectively managing supply chain.
3. Learn technical material on inventory theory, risk pooling, and optimization. This will also sharpen your general analytic and problem-solving skills.
4. Being able to address real business issues from the angle of inter-firm or inter-department relationships.
courses.course_syllabus: Particular topics include the understanding the supply chain, the strategic configuration of supply chains, distribution strategy, inventory management, instabilities caused by inadequate information-sharing, outsourcing, procurement (including e-markets), designing products for improved supply chain performance, strategic alliances, optimization approaches to strategic and tactical problems, the issues and opportunities brought by the Internet and the rise of e-business, and the many synergies between information technology and decision technology.
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings: Class handouts, including cases; extra write-ups; and slides.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Simchi-Levi D, Kaminsky P., Simchi-Levi E., Designing & Managing the Supply Chain, concepts, strategies & case studies, McGraw-Hill Irwin.
2. Chopra S. Meindl P. Supply Chain Management, strategy, planning, and operations, Pearson Prentice Hall.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Web Design and Authoring
courses.description: This course provides students with the basic knowledge required for designing and developing state-of-the-art interactive sites in the WWW. The primary focus will be on using Java Applets and JSP Web server pages to create Web business applications that can handle user requests and activate the relevant business processes. As the power of Web business applications relies heavily on access to the content of available databases, this course will also explore the technologies that have gained wide attention in the business information technology sectors, such as Java Database Connectivity (JDBC) and the Extensible Markup Language (XML). No prior programming knowledge is required.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) understand the basic constructs in Java programming.
(2) identify the major features in Web design and user navigation.
(3) recognize the issues in interface design.
(4) understand the real-world Web applications from design to implementation.
(5) understand the basic rationale of the concepts in n-tier Web applications, both in client- and server-sides.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Web Business Applications using Java
• Basic Elements/Control Flows in Java
• Classes and Objects in Java
• Web Interface Design
• Designing Site Structure and Navigation
• Other Interface Design Issues
• Interaction with Databases
• Concepts in Java Server Pages (JSP)
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings:

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Mining for Business Intelligence
courses.description: This course will focus on data analysis and decision making in organization and across organizational boundaries. Learn how to use Business Intelligence (BI) tools to produce the valuable information to decision makers in the organization. This course will also introduce the fundamental data mining techniques (e.g. classification, clustering, market basket). Student will learn how to capture the right knowledge, providing it to the right user at the right time.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Information Systems Practicum
courses.description: This course bridges the gap between classroom and real world. It requires students to complete a real-world information systems project, in collaboration with a company or organization. A minimum of three and a maximum of five students are required to form a project team, under the joint supervision of a MIS faculty member and a senior executive of the sponsoring company.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) work with IT/business professionals on real-world IT project
(2) understand the most current IT issues/management/trend in the commercial sector
(3) understand how real-world projects are managed and executed in a group setting
(4) improve their knowledge of real-world project development
(5) develop the skills (communication and leadership) required to complete IT projects
courses.course_syllabus: Project management (students are monitored and advised in group, depending on their selected project).
courses.feedback_evaluation: We have regular group meetings throughout the semester.
courses.required_readings: Readings vary, depending on student's selected project. The company supervisor may assign several internal documents or reports for students to read so that they can understand and complete their project.
courses.recommended_readings: Students have to search the library or internet to retrieve relevant documents, articles, reports to complete their project.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Supply Chain and Logistics Analytics
courses.description: This course first reviews the fundamentals of supply chain management and logistics management, and then examines how business analytics can be used to improve the competitiveness of supply chains and logistics processes. We will discuss the strategic role of supply chain management in global competition and the effective decision-making in the various areas of supply chain. The integrative role of logistics within the supply chain and the many logistics issues confronting logistic service providers will be examined. We will explore applying such analytics as data mining, forecasting, and optimization on demand planning, supply chain planning, and logistics planning. Business analytics can be used to predict and diagnose managerial problems in supply chain and logistics management, tracking most profitable products, identifying product quality issues, and better forecasting raw material needs.
courses.course_syllabus:
Review of basic concepts in supply chain management
• Configuration of a supply chain
• Integration of information, money, and physical goods
• From raw materials to customer needs
• Performance and visibility of a supply chain

Review of basic concepts in logistics management
• Overview of logistics functions
• Exporting and importing logistics
• Outsourcing and collaboration with logistics service providers
• Aviation logistics and marine logistics

Solve problems in supply chain and logistics management using business analytics
• Overview of business analytics
• Via cases and models, explore how problems in supply chains can be identified and solved based on data collected
• Discuss relevant business analytics software
courses.feedback_evaluation: CTE by end of the term
courses.required_readings:
Marshall Fisher and Ananth Raman, The New Science of Retailing: How Analytics are Transforming the Supply Chain and Improving Performance, Harvard Business Press.
Gerald Feigin, Supply Chain Planning and Analytics: The Right Product in the Right Place at the Right Time, Business Expert Press.

Chopra S., Meindl P., Supply Chain Management, strategy, planning, and operations, Pearson Prentice Hall.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Process Analytics
courses.description: This course aims to enhance the knowledge and skills related to business process management and improvement, with an emphasis on the applications of analysis and simulation tools. A simulation package will be introduced and will be used to evaluate business process performance and identify possibility of process improvement. The knowledge learnt from the course can help improve scientific competence to deal with practical problems in various settings related to business process management.

• Managing process variability and quality
• Process synchronization and improvement

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Current and Regional Issues in Supply Chain and Logistics Management
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the current issues in supply chain and logistics management that are of special relevance to Hong Kong and mainland China. Hong Kong, a gateway (for Pearl River Delta) and a transshipment hub (for mainland China and other parts of Asia), houses many local and international logistics service providers. In this course, we examine the regional logistics industries that are of special relevance to Hong Kong and mainland China, as well as their principal agents. These agents include freight forwarders, warehousing operators, airlines, terminal operators, integrators, trucking operators, customs and electronic agents, etc. We will discuss the respective roles of these agents in the management of logistics within a supply chain. Recent trends in trade, distribution, and adoption of IT for cargo logistics are covered.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course provides an overview of the current issues in supply chain and logistics management that are of special relevance to Hong Kong and mainland China. In this course, we examine the logistic infrastructure in the region, as well as the logistics industries and their principal agents. We first introduce the current developments in various transportation modes. We then will discuss the respective roles of the principal agents in the management of logistics within a supply chain. Recent trends in trade, distribution, and adoption of IT for cargo logistics are covered.
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Understand the current and regional issues in Supply Chain and Logistics Management and how they contribute to the success of the firm.
2. Understand the important of integration between Hong Kong and PRD.
3. Understand the strengths and weaknesses of regional polices, and how different stakeholders respond to these policies.
4. Under how supply chain and logistics management are practiced in PRD and in China in general.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction - logistics process and supply chain, review of key concepts with an international perspective
• Air and sea cargo in Asia and Hong Kong
• HK's logistics infrastructure
• Agents and the shipping process
• PRD and HK – regional logistics issues
• Mainland China – regional logistics issues
• IT in SC and L management
• Emerging trends in supply chain and logistics

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Microeconomic Theory
courses.description: This course is on advanced microeconomic theory. Topics include individual decision theory (consumer theory, production theory, choice under uncertainty), game theory (static and dynamic games under complete and incomplete information), and equilibrium and market failure (general equilibrium, principal-agent problems, economics of information, auctions, bargaining, and market design).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Accountancy; or MPhil-PhD Business Administration; or MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology; or MPhil-PhD Finance; or MPhil-PhD Marketing
courses.course_syllabus:
A. Individual Decision Making
1. consumer: preference, utility, demand
2. production: profit, cost
3. choice under uncertainty: expected utility, risk aversion, stochastic dominance

B. Game Theory
4. static games of complete information: dominance, Nash equilibrium
5. dynamic games of complete information: backward induction, subgame perfect equilibrium, folk theorem, Markovian refinement
6. games of incomplete information: Bayesian Nash equilibrium, perfect Bayesian equilibrium

C. Equilibrium and Market Failure
7. competitive market and general equilibrium: welfare theorems
8. market power: monopoly, oligopoly
9. information economics: lemon market, communication, search
10. allocative mechanism: contest, auction, bargaining
11. market design: assignment, matching
12. theory of contract and mechanism design: screening, moral hazard, adverse selection
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings:

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Macroeconomics in a Globalized Era
courses.description: The course begins by constructing a simplified model of the macro economy. This is intended to help organize your discussion of issues confronting an economy. Every opportunity is taken to reinforce the economic concepts with current data, particularly for the U.S. and China. We then proceed to examine the policy instruments used to steer an economy towards the objectives of sustainable growth, stable inflation and low unemployment. Broadly speaking, these policy tools are monetary policy, implemented by a country's central bank, and fiscal policy implemented by the government when it makes expenditure and taxation decisions. We extend our exposition of traditional monetary policy to explain the Federal Reserve's quantitative easing, as well as the essential factors contributing to the financial crisis which necessitated this unconventional monetary policy. We then move onto the interactions between economies as captured in their respective balance of payment accounts and exchange rate movements. Fluctuations in China's RMB will be closely analyzed at this point and open the door for an in-depth look into China's domestic imbalances. We also examine Hong Kong's unique currency board system under-pinning our linked exchange rate.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA
courses.learning_outcomes: Students should be able to critically analyze current macroeconomic issues, both domestic and global, and formulate solutions to economic challenges and problems.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Gross Domestic Product - Measuring a Nation's Output
2. Aggregate Demand-Aggregate Supply Model
3. The Inflation-Unemployment Trade-Off
4. Changes in the Money Supply - The Multiplier Process
5. Monetary Policy
6. Fiscal Policy
7. Open-Economy Macroeconomics - Basic Concepts
8. Hong Kong's Currency Board
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.

courses.description: This course provides students with a basic understanding of the state of the global economy and macroeconomic policy. Topics include national income accounting, unemployment, inflation, monetary and fiscal policies, and international economic interactions. Applications of economic theories to current macroeconomic phenomena will be emphasized.

courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to understand, explain and apply:
1. Economic variables such as gross domestic product (GDP), consumer price index (CPI), unemployment rate, and economic growth rate.
2. Economic models that explain the business cycles.
3. The role of banking sector, the creation of money, the role of central bank and its impacts on monetary policy.
4. The role of government and effects of fiscal policy.
5. The international economy in the context of foreign exchanges and balance of payments (BOP).

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Analytics
courses.description: The major objective of this course is to provide students with real life examples of the application of quantitative methods, such as business statistics and operations research, to help business executives solve problems in competitive business environments.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA; or EMBA (Chinese)
courses.learning_outcomes: The major objective of this course is to provide students with basic understanding on the most important quantitative techniques used in business analysis. Although the course is quantitative in nature, we will try to avoid dealing with complicated mathematical theories whenever possible and, instead, stress on the intuition and logic behind the mathematical models and their managerial implications. Except for some illustrative examples in which problems may be solved manually, we will make heavy use of the popular Microsoft Excel and some of its add-in programs (e.g., Solver and StatTools) to solve most of the problems. It is our hope that, by the end of the term, you will feel comfortable about using Excel to analyse data and solve many of your business problems. More importantly, after completing this course, we hope you will develop a habit of thinking your problems in logical ways.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction; Decision Making Diagnosis
- Summarizing Data with Tables and Graphs
- Normal Distribution, Sampling Distribution, and Statistical Inference
- Applications of Statistical Inferences
- Regression Analysis
- Linear Programming: Introduction
- Linear Programming: Applications
- Integer Programming
- Nonlinear Programming

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Strategic Value of Innovation and Technology
courses.description: As an organization gets bigger and more mature, there is a tendency to soften up on the original entrepreneurial and innovative culture. In the digital economy, competitors are coming from not just the same industry but also innovative tech giants and start-ups. The need for faster change and continued growth can only be met with increased flexibility, agility and innovation. Corporate leaders need to think and act like entrepreneurs to stay relevant and competitive in the Digital Economy. Fortunately, innovation and entrepreneurship are not just for tech giants and start-ups. They can be learned. This course is designed for business leaders and professionals to acquire an even greater level of entrepreneurial, innovative and agile mindset and capabilities as the ultimate source of competitive advantage.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course aims to empower students to leverage on innovation and technology to create values to their companies, customers and key stakeholder. The students will also learn how to make challenging decisions in a corporate innovation and entrepreneurial environment.

Upon completion of the course, the participants are expected to be able to:

A. Develop an innovation strategy that aligns with the corporate strategy

B. Manage innovation as a science

C. Master the key success factors for corporate innovation

D. Learn the best practices of innovation from successful entrepreneurs and cultivate intrapreneurs

E. Collaborate and engage with open innovation ecosystems for value co-creation
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Old Economy Vs Digital Economy

- Apart from the companies in your same industry, who else are your major competitors?

- Why do we need to care or even worry about these competitors?

- What can we learn from these new competitors or disruptors?

2. Innovation Vs Customer Centricity

- What is the most critical success factor for leaders in the Digital Economy?

- How does customer centricity relate to innovation?

- How important is “Empathy” for our innovation?

3. Execution for Strategy Vs Search for Innovation

- How can we formulate an innovation strategy aligned with business strategy?

- Can innovation be managed like a science?

- What are the best practices to generate, cultivate and scale ideas to empower innovation?

- What is an innovation strategy? To be more precise, what is a great innovation strategy?

- How can we align our company on clear innovation objectives?

- How can we focus on our traditional business and innovation at the same time?

- How to create a culture of innovation?

- How should we innovate like leading tech companies?

4. Internal Innovation Vs External Collaboration

- What are the limitations of Internal Innovation?

- What is an ecosystem? What stakeholders are in the ecosystem?

- Why should we engage with the ecosystem? How can we leverage on the ecosystem?

- What are the challenges in collaborating with the ecosystem and how do we resolve them?

5. Entrepreneurship Vs Intrapreneurship

- Why “Entrepreneurship” is getting more and more critical for corporate innovation?

- What is Intrapreneurship? What are the major similarities and differences between entrepreneurs and intrapreneurs?

- How do corporate leaders nurture intrapreneurship in their companies? What are the key challenges to cultivate intrapreneurs in corporates?

6. Experience-driven Vs Data-driven

- Why do today’s enterprises need to be data-driven?

- What are the key benefits of being a data-driven enterprise?

- What are the shortfalls of experience-driven management?

- What is data-driven culture? Why is it important?

- How do you nurture data culture in your company? What are the major challenges? How do you resolve these challenges?
