courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Econometric Theory and Applications
courses.description: This course is designed for business Ph.D. students who need to apply econometrics in their research. The major contents of this course will focus on two parts. The first part will cover fundamental econometrics topics such as ordinary least squares, instrumental variable estimation, panel data models, and generalized linear model. The second part will cover topics about business causal inference by either randomized field/lab experiments or natural experiments such as matching, difference-in-differences, and regression discontinuity design. This course is a graduate econometrics course that emphasizes application in pratice. Knowledge of multivariate calculus, linear algebra, statistics, and econometrics at the undergraduate level is preferred.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Accountancy; or MPhil-PhD Business Administration; or MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology; or MPhil-PhD Finance; or MPhil-PhD Marketing
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students can:
• Understand the basic approaches in econometrics such as OLS, IV, and GLM
• Design a randomized experiment and test certain treatment effects
• Use natural experiment to identify the causal effect of a business policy
• Know how to apply econometrics with frequently-used software such as Stata and computer languages such as R
• Improve their data analysis skills
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I:
- Ordinary least squares
- Instrumental variable and dynamic panel
- Generalized linear model

Part II:
- Experiment Design
- Matching
- Difference-in-differences
- Regression discontinuity designs
- Synthetic control method

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Operations Management
courses.description: Efficient and effective operations enable firms to gain a competitive advantage by creating cost leadership, quality superiority, and capability of meeting customer demands quickly. This course will introduce concepts, issues, tools, and techniques in designing, managing and improving business processes. Topics encompass: operations strategy, process analysis, quality management, and supply chain management, etc. Cases and business best practices will be discussed in the course to demonstrate that companies can use (and have used) the principles from this course to significantly enhance their competitiveness.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Operations and Supply Chains Strategies
courses.description: Efficiency and effectiveness of operations and supply chains provide significant contributions to a firm's competitive advantage. This course will focus on strategic aspects of managing operations and supply chain processes that enable a firm to match its supply with the demand for its goods and services. The course will discuss concepts, techniques and strategies for managing process capacity and flexibility, demand and supply variability, and supply chain integration. It will also explore the challenges and opportunities offered by increasingly complex global supply chains for firms in the greater China region. Cases and business best practices will be discussed in the course to demonstrate that companies can use (and have used) the principles from this course to significantly enhance their competitiveness.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA; or EMBA (Chinese)
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Develop a set of principles that will enable a business manager to make strategically sound operations decisions.
2. Develop skills in analyzing and improving the performance of an operations process.
3. Recognize the strategic importance of supply chain management in a global economic environment.
4. Understand major concepts and issues in the development of supply chain strategies.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Quantitative Analysis for Decision Making
courses.description: The objective of this course is to introduce some of the most popular quantitative methods used in analysing business problems to students with no or only limited prior knowledge in this area. The course emphasizes the importance of decision making based on data. The lectures focus primarily upon understanding basic concepts about data analysis and statistical inferences and topics covered include descriptive statistics, probability, inferential statistics, and regression analysis. To free students from the trouble of learning and memorizing technical details of the analytical methods, computer software will be used extensively to perform the analysis so that the focus can be placed on understanding, interpreting, and communicating of the analytical results in a variety of business contexts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to:
1. develop basic skills for quantitative analysis
2. learn how to interpret and communicate quantitative evidence
3. learn how to use quantitative analysis for facilitating decision making processes

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: AI and Big Data Strategies
courses.description: The course brings insight and expertise to leveraging artificial intelligence and big data in business so students can harness the power of analytics and gain a true business advantage. Based on a practical framework with supporting methodology and hands-on exercises, this course helps identify where and how AI and big data can help entrepreneurs transform their businesses. Students will learn how to exploit new sources of customer, product, and operational data, coupled with advanced analytics and data science, to optimize key processes, uncover monetization opportunities, and create new sources of competitive differentiation.

2. understand how AI and big data can help entrepreneurs transform their businesses

courses.title: Managerial Economics
courses.description: In this course economic analysis is applied to the management decision-making process. Topics to be treated include management decision-making under different situations, demand measurement and forecasting, production and cost, pricing, and capital budgeting. The course consists of lectures, exercises and discussions, and student group presentations of assigned problems and cases.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or EMBA (Chinese)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Course Learning Objectives
• The students are expected to understand topics such as demand and supply, consumption and production, market structures, game theory, etc.
• The students are expected to apply the theories learnt to real world managerial practices.
• The students are expected to provide in-depth analyses of the development of the Chinese economy and the world economy.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Analytics and Digital Innovation
courses.description: This course will explore how business data and big data play a key role in business model, service as well as process innovations. The unique ramifications of mastering the technical and managerial aspects of business analytics that lead to digital innovations will be discussed. The course will not only survey the latest enabling technologies and their applications in business management but also provide a holistic overview of the data analytics models and tools. Emphases are placed on understanding of intuitions behind these tools as well as their applications in various areas of management, including marketing, finance and operations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to learn principles and practices of:
1. managing and integrating business data and big data for business analytics
2. applying enabling technologies for digital innovations
3. data analytics tools and their applications in business management

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Managing Service Operations
courses.description: This course is designed for students to learn the latest theories, frameworks, concepts, techniques and to apply them in meeting the special challenges of managing service operations. The focus is to develop analytical thinking skills that will enable students contemplating careers in services to develop, evaluate and implement strategies for a wide range of service producing organizations. Topics will include: 1). the importance and economics of customer loyalty and approaches to build customer loyalty; 2). formulation and implementation of service strategies and the strategic service vision for greater business success; 3). management of the operational behavior of customers in service delivery; 4). design of sustainable service models that successfully incorporate a customer’s operating role; 5). analyses of customer data to inform managerial decision making; and 6). management of changes in service settings.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Supply Chain Sustainability Management
courses.description: This course explores the design and management of environmentally and socially responsible supply chains. Governments, businesses, organizations, and consumers are increasingly aware of the importance of sustainability. We will first cover some basic concepts and processes of supply chain management. We will then study how and why companies integrate environmental and social sustainability concerns in managing their operations and supply chains, from product design, sourcing, to production and logistics. The course will explore the trade-offs between profit/costs and sustainability in decision making processes. The role of technology and innovation in promoting sustainable practices will also be discussed. We will use a mix of cases to understand the factors that drive companies’ sustainability effort and identify the opportunities and potential challenges.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Sustainable Global Business
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Be familiarized with the basics of supply chain management

• Comprehend the practices of sustainable supply chain management.

• Understand the challenges and opportunities in sustainable supply chain management.

• Design sustainable supply chain strategies.

• Apply technology and innovation in driving supply chain sustainability

* Life cycle assessment (LCA)
* Sustainable product design
* Sustainable sourcing and procurement
* Carbon reduction: regulations and markets
* Midterm
* Sustainable production and logistics
* Circular economics
* Socially responsible operations
* Innovative business models
* Project presentations

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Financial Data Modeling and Analysis
courses.description: This course is designed to cover mathematical and statistical/econometric techniques to financial issues, i.e. regression, time-series methods, forecasting models and simulation in financial applications. It shows students how to apply such techniques in the context of finance. For example, discussion of a number of distributions pays special attention to heavy tail, skewness and other distribution features with regard to financial return analysis. Time-series analyses aim to explain the important influence of time-dependence in making economical predictions. Regression models cover CAPM as well as multifactor models to connote the cross-section relations among financial returns. GARCH and other volatility models introduce the related applications in risk management context. The course involves extensive use of real data examples and hands-on examples.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
courses.course_syllabus:
The course covers the following topics:
Topic 1. Data Modeling and Analysis
- Readings: Chapter 4, Why heavy tail? Readings: Minsky (1986); Taleb (2010)
- Readings: Chapters 5-7
Topic 2. Time Series Models
- Readings: Chapters 9, 10
- Trading strategies; Readings: Conrad and Kaul, Lo and Mackinlay
Topic 3. Regression Models
- Readings: Chapters 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, & 17, Carhart
Topic 4. Volatility modeling and VaR
- Readings: Chapters 18, 19

• Peter Bernstein, Against the Gods: The Remarkable Story of Risk, Wiley.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Macro and Micro Economics
courses.description: This course is to provide students with basic understanding of modern economics of the firm and of the economy as a whole. The market forces of demand and supply as well as the firm’s price and output decisions under various forms of market structure will be analysed. Issues related to regulation and competition on the market will be studied. At the macro level, topics such as national income and its determination, international trade theory and commercial policies, the foreign exchange market, and the balance of international payments will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will:
- be able to think economic and financial issues critically
- develop problem-solving skills
- understand market structure, macroeconomic variables and government regulations and policies in national and international perspectives
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is divided into two parts: microeconomics and macroeconomics. The microeconomics part mainly discusses how the market works, focusing on demand and supply, price mechanisms, consumer and producer behavior, different types of markets and their operations, and business strategies. The macroeconomics part mainly discusses macroeconomic behavior, focusing on national income, unemployment, inflation, economic growth, economic cycles, interest rates, government macroeconomic policies, banking systems, international trade, and exchange rates.

courses.description: This course introduces fundamental concepts and techniques for analysing risk and formulating sound decisions in uncertain environments. Approximately half of the course focuses on probability theory and decision analysis including decision trees, decision criteria, the value of information, and simulation techniques. The remainder of the course examines statistical methods for interpreting and analysing data including sampling concepts, regression analysis, and hypothesis testing. Applications include inventory management, demand analysis, lotteries and gambling, portfolio analysis, insurance, auctions, surveys and opinion polls, environmental contamination and failure analysis. The course emphasizes analytical techniques and concepts that are broadly applicable to business decisions.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Modelling Methodology in Management Science
courses.description: This course introduces students to some basic issues in the design and completion of a research project in business and economics. These issues include the initial choice of a research problem, the use of quantitative vs. qualitative methods for undertaking that research, potential pitfalls that may be met along the way, and the presentation of results in a scholarly manuscript. Fundamental modelling methodologies will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand basic modelling methodologies in management science
2. To choose a topic for scientific research in the area of management science
3. To identify an appropriate modelling methodology for a given research topic
4. To organize results obtained from a research in management science and present them academically
courses.course_syllabus: This course intends to discuss the principal aspects of modeling and solving management science problems. The emphasis is on the many aspects of modeling business problems: identification of decision variables and parameter, formulation of objective function, and examination of the logical and physical constraints of the problem. The course is organized according to the major analytical methods. Solution procedure will be discussed but will not be the primary focus. Structural aspects of the methods will be briefly reviewed and discussed whenever appropriate. For each methodology, we will spend a lot of time on examining how it can be applied in academic research.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Platform and Business Strategies
courses.description: Success in business needs strategies. The advances of information technology have given business strategies a new dimension: building computer-mediated networks to facilitate transactions over e-platforms. The examples include Amazon, Google, Spotify, iTunes, Alibaba, Uber, Airbnb, and many other B2B, B2C, and C2C platforms. The e-platform business has network effect following demand-side scale economies that sees the value of a product from the willingness-to-pay of customers. This creates new perspectives of business strategies on pricing, platform products, envelopment attacks, winner-takes-all effect, and cannibalization. This course discusses how to run a successful business with e-platforms.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
courses.learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this course, students should be able to:
1) be familiar with major managerial issues in Internet business,
2) understand how to run a platform business, and
3) be familiar with the competition strategies in Internet platform business.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Platform Business
2. The Network Effect
3. Products and Platforms
4. Pricing Strategies
5. Adopting Strategies with Network Effect
6. Winner-Takes-All Market
7. Redefining the Market: The Envelopment Attack
8. Going to the Market: First Mover Disadvantage?
9. Going to the Market: Cannibalization

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Research Methods in Microeconomics
courses.description:
This course is a combination of two separate mini-courses.

In the first half of the course we take a microeconomic perspective to analyze a number of important resource-allocating systems that are widely used in real life, including auctions, matching mechanisms, and trading platforms for financial assets. For each system we study its objective, structure, and actual performance. We will focus on the theoretical aspects of these systems, but will also examine empirical findings on how well they function.

The second half of course surveys modern methods of applied micro-econometric research. We will begin by reviewing the Rubin Causal Model, its relationship with structural models, and the econometric definition of identification. We will then proceed to consider a number of econometric estimators, research designs, and inferential methods.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil/PhD Decision Sciences and Managerial Economics or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Applied Economics:

The goal of this mini course is to introduce the students to some important economic mechanisms, and moreover to familiarize them with the analytical tools and perspectives of studying these mechanisms. For each general topic, the instructor will give an extended overview of it, and then organize the students to present classical papers on the topic, while the instructor shall supplement the presentations by providing his own comments along the way. At the end of the class students are expected to write a survey/review in a unified framework.

Applied Econometrics:

The goal of this mini course is for students to learn a set of statistical tools and research designs that are useful in conducting high-quality empirical research on topics in Applied Microeconomics and related fields. Since most applied economic research examines questions with direct policy implications, this course will focus on methods for estimating causal effects. This course differs from many other econometrics courses in that it is oriented towards applied practitioners rather than future econometricians. It therefore emphasizes research design (relative to statistical technique) and applications (relative to theoretical proofs), though it covers some of each.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Visualization and Business Intelligence
courses.description: In the increasingly competitive world, the need for timely analysis of constantly expanding data to gain business intelligence and communication of the results to the key decision makers has become a vital part of a company’s operation. In the past, business intelligence used to be in the domain of IT specialists. With the advent of self-service data visualization and business intelligence tools, such as Excel BI toolkit, now anyone with adequate training can produce their own analyses with minimal support from central IT. The aim of this course is to introduce to students the Excel BI toolkit that has become an integral part of Excel since Excel 2013. Designed to handle very large amount of data, the toolkit consists of four add-ins, namely, Power Query, Power Pivot, Power View, and Power Map. Students will learn how to use these add-ins to gain business intelligence. Students who are interested in taking this course are expected to have at least intermediate level and preferably advanced level of Excel skills.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should:
1) have solid understanding of Excel data model and be able to design one when necessary,
2) be able to use Power Query to find and load external data and, when necessary, to shape the data into the desired forms and formats before loading into the model,
3) be able to use DAX language and Power Pivot to perform sophisticated data analysis to get key insights into business performance,
4) be able to use Power View to design interactive reports and dashboards to summarize information into instantly digestible analytics that provide at-a-glance visibility into business performance, and
5) be able to perform geospatial analysis with Power Map.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Data Visualization and Business Intelligence with Excel – the traditional way
2. Data Visualization and Business Intelligence with Excel BI toolkits – the revolutionary way
3. Introduction to Excel Data Model
4. Data Analysis with Power Pivot and Power Chart
5. Building Interactive Reports and Dashboards with Power View
6. Geospatial Analysis with Power Map and 3D Maps
7. Exploring Data with Power Query

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Multivariate Statistics
courses.description: This course provides students with the basic multivariate analysis principles, techniques, and applications based on statistics theory. Major topics include factor analysis, multiple discriminant analysis, multivariate analysis of variance, cluster analysis, principle component analysis, etc. The techniques introduced will be useful in conducting quantitative research in various areas in business and economics including management, marketing, and management information system. Applications of the techniques to real – world economic and business problems will be emphasized. Statistical software will also be introduced to familiarize students with the application of multivariate analysis techniques in their research.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
courses.learning_outcomes: After completion of the course, students are expected to learn various multivariate statistics techniques, such as multi-normal distribution, cluster analysis, discriminant analysis, principal analysis, factor analysis, canonical analysis, SEMs, etc. Applications of the above methods with the help of multivariate statistical analysis software to various empirical research areas in economics, finance, management, etc., are also expected.
courses.course_syllabus: The course discusses the basic principles, techniques and applications of multivariate statistical analysis. It covers major topics including canonical correlation, factor analysis, multivariate analysis of variance, principle component analysis, time series analysis, structural equation modeling, etc. The techniques introduced will be useful in conducting quantitative business research. Applications of the techniques to accounting, economics, finance, management, marketing, and management information system, etc. will be emphasized. Statistical software of multivariate statistical analysis will also be introduced.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Economics of Information Systems
courses.description: The use of economics as a reference discipline for IS research has gained significant recognition over the past twenty years. This course is designed to introduce the research stream (as known as Economics of IS) to Ph.D. students with economic theories, models, and methodologies used in IS research. Specifically, this course deals with classical research questions, methods, and findings which form the backbone of Economics of IS. In addition, the course extends its focus and also covers the growing field of behavioral economics and its connection with IS research. Although the course relies primarily on IS literature, it is appropriate for Ph.D. students with a variety of backgrounds including Information Systems, Operations Management, Strategy, Marketing, and Economics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of this seminar, students will have an understanding of Economics of IS research and its connection with behavioral economics. Moreover, students should be able to evaluate the quality of different studies and assess their respective contributions. Lastly, students will develop their ability to write research articles using economic theories, models, and methods covered in the course.

courses.title: Advanced BE Research Seminar
courses.description: This seminar course provides students with a broad exposure to research in Business Economics (BE). It will cover the development of current research topics such as game theory, information economics, firm and contract theory, industrial organization, and other topics related to microeconomics. Students are expected to read assigned papers thoroughly prior to classes and be able to discuss the paper's key assumptions and how those assumptions influence the paper;s key findings. The contribution of the papers to the literature will also be discussed.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Decision Models and Applications
courses.description: This course covers the principal quantitative techniques used in solving financial, marketing, and operations problems in the private and public sectors. Topics include decision under uncertainty, Markov chain, linear programming, classical optimization, dynamic programming, and integer programming.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces the most commonly used quantitative methods in business and shows how these tools can be implemented using computer applications. It includes two major parts. The first part consists of three modules and introduces three types of commonly used optimization models for decision-making problems without uncertainty. The second part consists of two modules and introduces two commonly used approaches for solving decision-making problems with uncertainty. More details are provided below.

Module 1. Course Overview
Module 2: Linear Programming (Parts I, II & III)
Module 3: Integer Programming (Parts I & II)
Module 4: Non-linear Programming
Module 5: Decision Analysis (Parts I & II)
Module 6: Business Simulation (Parts I & II)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Wayne L. Winston, S. Christian Albright, Practical Management Science.
2. Stephen G. Powell, Kenneth R. Baker, Business Analytics: The Art of Modeling with Spreadsheets.
3. Dimitris Bertsimas, Robert M. Freund, Data, Models, and Decisions: The Fundamentals of Management Science.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Advanced MIS Research Seminar
courses.description: This course provides students with a broad-based exposure to research in MIS and its research methodologies, including survey, case study, experimental design, and field work. Various theories used in MIS research will also be discussed to provide students with background on approaches to theory building and theory testing. Seminal MIS articles will be reviewed to orient students to the emergence of MIS discipline and its research tradition and trend.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Possess relevant knowledge and skills in academic research
2. Able to propose intelligent and insightful research questions, along with their proposed research methods
3. Understand and able to apply varied research methodologies and techniques to MIS research
4. Possess the ability and experience in critiquing academic research works
5. Able to prepare and present IS research proposals for research grants
courses.course_syllabus:
Markets, organizations, and individuals use a wide variety of structures to co-ordinate resource production and allocation. Dramatic changes in information technology (IT) and business activities are forcing firms to come up with new ways of organizing work. Similarly, new types of digital information goods, much lower search costs, innovative ways of doing marketing, management, finance and human resource all lead to the disruption of old business models and creation of new ones.
This course uses economic theory to investigate the roles of information and technology in the existing diversity of organizations and markets and in enabling the creating of new organizational forms. The class is designed for PhD students in management, economics, information technology, marketing, operations management, organizational behavior and related disciplines. For economists, this class offers the opportunity to apply economic tools to understand how information technology and information in general affect organizations and markets. For non-economists, this class offers an exposure to fundamental ideas in the economics of information, organizations, and markets. This course covers quantitative research methodologies in Economics of IS. It consists of three components: Methodology, Economics of IS Research Topics, and Writing and Publishing. The main goal is to prepare PhD students to produce publication quality research using tools from information economics.
We will cultivate a culture of collaborative learning. In particular, in this seminar class, students come prepared to engage in thoughtful discussions of the materials. Students are asked to write informal, short memos prior to several of the classes. These memos will generally be responses to some questions or issues we pose prior to each class. In addition, each student will be asked to present at least one of the research papers as part of the class discussion.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Research Sem in Operations & SCM
courses.description: This seminar is designed to provide students with the latest knowledge on research issues, theories and methodologies in the areas of Operations and Supply Chain Management. Students will be required to read research papers, critique and synthesize other people's research work, and identify areas for future research. They are also required to present and discuss other people's research and their own research proposals. The instructor and scholars from different universities will also be invited to present their latest research. Topical areas will include Operations Supply Chain Strategy, Total Quality Management, Service Operations Management, Innovation and New Product Development, Lean Thinking, Business Process Improvement/Innovation, Relationship Management and Supply Chain Integration, Supply Chain/Logistics Network Design and other topics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Familiarize the topics chosen by the course instructor and the related literature and research development
2. Understand the related concepts and methodologies
3. Able to apply the methods and techniques to identify and solve research problems
courses.course_syllabus: This course covers the fundamental theories and algorithms of stochastic dynamic programming (Markov decision processes) and reinforcement learning (RL). It aims to provide the central ideas of how they are applied to model and solve various problems in different contexts. The first part of the course will focus on MDPs. We start with finite-stage models and then discuss infinite-stage models under discounted/undiscounted return and average return criteria. In the second part, we will cover popular RL algorithms like Q-learning and temporal difference learning.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Artificial Intelligence for Business Research
courses.description:
Modern artificial intelligence (AI) has largely reshaped our world over the past 10 years. This course is designed to prepare students from a broad range of business areas (e.g. Finance, Marketing, Accounting, Management, Operations, Information Systems, Business Economics, Hotel Management etc.) for the cutting-edge research that connects AI and business. At a high-level, students taking this course will learn the followings:
• Fundamental concepts/methods of machine learning (ML) and AI that are used in business research ;• How business researchers have utilized ML/AI and what managerial questions have been addressed by ML/AI in the past several years ;• The huge mismatch between AI technologies and the adoption of AI technologies in our fields.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Accountancy; or MPhil-PhD Business Administration; or MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology; or MPhil-PhD Finance; or MPhil-PhD Marketing

courses.recommended_readings:

* Sutton, R. S., & Barto, A. G. *Reinforcement learning: An introduction*. MIT press.

The art and science of economic modeling for this purpose makes use of the principles and the tools derived from the studies of information economics, games, industrial organization and the related fields. The course is conducted in a variety of formats including lectures, cases studies and other activities. Operation and strategic issues covered in the course include setting prices, designing contracts, managing firm boundaries, controlling strategic information, analyzing entry and exit, and formulating competitive strategy.

courses.title: Risk and Operations Analytics
courses.description: This course introduces the analysis of key issues related to the design and management of business operations using quantitative tools such as linear, integer, and non-linear programming, regression, and statistical analysis. It covers important topics such as revenue management and dynamic pricing, inventory theory, production control and scheduling, and risk management in supply chains, among others, and uses mathematical modeling, spreadsheet analysis, case studies, and simulation to deliver materials. The course introduces Monte Carlo simulations with Excel and Crystal Ball, focusing on their applications in solving business operations problems.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Fintech and Its Applications

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01
Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description:
Advance in information technology has already started a revolution in the financial industry. Every part of the financial service system is affected, from daily payment to long-term investment, from efficiency gain to logic transformation. The pace of change is fast. Too fast to catch, yet too critical to miss. Institutions which can leverage the new technologies gain superior market insights, create new business models, and will become the future leaders of the financial service industry. Individuals who can understand and work with FinTech open new gates for investment and career development.

This course introduces FinTech and examines opportunities and challenges. It seeks to equip students with both a deep and practical understanding of emerging technology in the FinTech arena as well as the necessary coding skills to tackle future demand. We are going to cover topics such as the fundamentals of the financial service system, technology disruption, data management and visualization, financial data mining (Python), quantitative trading and artificial intelligence, crowdfunding, blockchain technology, and RegTech.

Applications on practical FinTech problems are emphasized with case discussions and programming assignments. While we will work with computer codes, this course does NOT assume any programming background from students.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through the learning of this course, students should be able to achieve the following goals:
1. Understand the basic concepts in FinTech, for example, disruptive innovation, business analytics, big data, quantitative trading, statistical arbitrage, unstructured data, text mining, deep learning, crowdfunding, peer-to-peer network, blockchain, regulatory sandbox, etc.
2. Explain the factors that determine the success and failure of IT-supported business initiatives in finance.
3. Explain the factors that determine the performance of a quantitative trading model.
4. Discuss the opportunities and challenges for specific innovative FinTech applications.
5. Read and write simple programs to implement data visualization, trading algorithms, text-mining techniques, blockchain applications, etc.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course contains the following modules. In group discussions, the lecturer will lead student groups in discussing cases, programming, or analyzing projects.

Module 1 Course Overview
- The FinTech revolution
- Technology disruption and business model innovation
- The future of financial market and financial services
- Group Discussion: Mobile payment

Module 2 Financial Services System
- Fundamentals of financial services
- Banking and risk management
- Trading and investment
- Data and data management

Module 3 Financial Programming I
- Statistics recap
- Python introduction
- Group Discussion: As simple as Python

Module 4 Analytics and the Art of Visualization
- Working with financial data
- Big data and analytics in finance
- Visualization tools
- Group Discussion: Designing a dashboard

Module 5 Smart Alpha
- Big data Alpha model
- Alpha model consideration
- Big data factors from text and other unstructured data
- Algo trading basics
- Machine learning algorithm
- AI and Deep Learning
- Robo-advisor in asset management
- Group Discussion: Programming for investment professionals

Module 6 Blockchain
- Democratizing finance
- Crowdfunding and financial inclusion
- Blockchain technology
- The token economy
- Group Discussion: ICO and blockchain project evaluation

Module 7 Fintech for Consumers
- Smart service delivery systems
- Mass customization in finance
- RegTech
- Emerging trend in consumer finance

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Blockchain and Its Application
courses.description:
Blockchain technology provides a dynamic shared ledger that enables peer-to-peer transfer of digital assets without any intermediaries, and is predicted to be a revolutionary technology that is just as impactful as the Internet. It is radically transforming financial services, supply chains, and other business services, as well as creating new opportunities for innovation.

This course aims to provide students with basic knowledge of Blockchain and its practical applications in various business fields. It introduces the basic concepts and technologies of Blockchain with the technology’s initial application, the cryptocurrency Bitcoin. Students will then gain an understanding of the commercial, technical, and public policy fundamentals of Blockchain technology and smart contracts in both public and private applications. Finally, the class will discuss current and potential Blockchain applications in various business domains.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through the learning of this course, students should be able to achieve the following outcomes.

1. Understand the basic concepts and technologies of Blockchain.
2. Understand the capabilities and limitations of Blockchain technology.
3. Understand examples of Blockchain newtworks, both public and private.
4. Discuss current and potential use cases of Blockchain in various fields.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course contains the following modules.

Module 1 (Week 1) Course Overview

* Course outline and logistics
* Intro to Blockchain

Module 2 (Week 2-3) Fundamentals of Blockchain

* Cryptography
* Consensus mechanism
* Ledgers

Module 3 (Week 4-5) Developments in Blockchain

* Smart contract
* Permissioned system

Module 4 (Week 6-7) Opportunities and challenges in Blockchain

* Technical challenges
* Policy challenges

Module 5 (Week 8-11) Assessment of use cases

* A framework for assessing a Blockchain-based use case
* Payments
* Central bank digital currencies
* Primary markets, ICOs, and venture capital
* Trade finance and supply chain
* Digital ID
* Static and dynamic registry
* Digital content

Module 6 (Week 12) Exam

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Communication and Networking
courses.description: This course discusses the concepts and principles of data communications and computer networks. It prepares students to make intelligent and informed decisions about moving voice, data, image and video between locations securely, by making them aware of the benefits, drawbacks, and effects related to various data communication technologies. Students will also learn how to make policy, design, and installation decisions related to planning and implementing data communication and network applications.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Information & Technology Management
courses.course_syllabus:
Possible topics include:
• Data transmission (such as analog and digital signals, data encoding techniques, error control, flow control, and multiplexing)
• Internet operations, including TCP/IP
• Local area network architecture and infrastructure
• Wide area network technology, protocols, and services
• Wireless local and wide area networks
• Network security
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Stallings, W. and Case, T. Business Data Communications.
• Fitzgerald, Dennis, and Durcikova. Business Data Communications and Networking.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Technology Startup-From Idea to Reality
courses.description: This is a practical course on entrepreneurial business management as a living skill to start, build and grow a technology enterprise. Learn by creating a new business based on the know-how and wisdom from Silicon Valley to Asia, including evaluating business opportunities, innovation, generating business model, business plan, team building, competition analysis, IP, financing, growth, Silicon Valley and Asian business culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The goal, road map, and entrepreneurship
2. Characteristics of the Billion $ startups - Unicorn
3. Entrepreneurial mindset and venture opportunities
4. How an Innovation Engine works
5. Creating a functional business model - from the ground up
6. Designing product that customers like
7. Marketing high tech product
8. Critical thinking for decision making, practicing the Oxford debate
9. Lean startup to test market feasibility
10. Selecting a venture finance partner
11. Corporate culture & business ethics
12. Building a sustainable business, project presentation.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings:
- Business model generation by Alexander Osterwalder & Yves Pigneur
- From Zero to one by Peter Thiel
- The Start up of you by Reid Hoffman, Ben Casnocha & Chris Yeh
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Technology Ventures by Thomas H. Byers / Richard C Dorf / Andrew J Nelson
2. Steve Jobs by Walter Issacson
3. The Innovators by Walter Issacson
4. InGenius by Tina Seelig
5. Value Proposition Design by Alexander Osterwalder, Yves Pigneur, Greg Bernarda, Alan Smith
6. Creative Confidence by Tom Kelley & David Kelley
7. Crossing the Chasm by Geoffrey A. Moore
8. Blizscaling by Reid Hoffman & Chris Yeh
9. The Alliance by Reid Hoffman, Ben Casnocha, & Chris Yeh
10. The Lean Startup by Eri

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: IT Law for Executives
courses.description:
Information technology becomes more and more important in our business sector. Issues relating to information technology and law, such as privacy and location surveillance, digital signature, copyright, outsourcing, anti-competition and contracts are essential to our daily life. This course examines the link between IT law and business operations; it offers a clear picture to students who are at executive level with no related legal background.

Topics will include introduction of the Hong Kong Legal System; Contract Law; Torts Law; internet impact on legal systems; IT and IP Laws in business operations and the latest Competition Ordinance.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management
courses.course_syllabus:
1) General Overview
2) Contract Laws
3) Torts Laws
4) IT Laws in Business Operations
5) IP Laws in Business operations

courses.description: This course bridges the gap between classroom and real world. It requires students to complete a real-world business analytics project, in collaboration with a company or organization. Students are required to form a project team, under the joint supervision of a teacher and an executive of the sponsoring company.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Data Visualization and Business Communication
courses.description: This course covers foundational perception principles, the art of designing impactful graphs, and strategies for clear, influential presentations. The course dives into the intricacies of effective data visualization and communication. The course invites some leading companies in different industries to share the skills they value in interviews and in work. Students are supposed to make presentations during classes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Business Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, students should be able to: (1) delve into the science of data visualization and the art of clear communication; (2) acquire techniques to simplify intricate data, ensuring clear, logical presentations tailored for diverse audience; (3) engage with foundational principles that enable effective communication, fostering understanding, and stimulating actionable outcomes.
courses.course_syllabus:
Content of the course:

Foundations of Perception in Data Visualization

* How to choose an effective visual, simple text, table, heatmap, scatter plots, line graph, bars, stacked vertical bar chart, waterfall chart, horizontal bar chart, area

Designing Graphs for Clarity

* Cognitive load, clutter, proximity, similarity, enclosure, closure, connection, lack of visual order, alignment, white space, non-strategic use of contrast,
* Decluttering: step-by-step, remove chart border, remove gridlines, remove data markers, clean up axis labels, label data directly, leverage consistent color

Slide Design for Optimal Communication

* Audience attention
* Preattentive attributes: bold, color, Italics, size, position

Utilizing Model Visuals in Presentation

* Line graph, annotated line graph with forecast
* 100% stacked bars, leveraging positive and negative stacked bars, horizontal stacked bars

Data-driven Storytelling

* Beginning: setting, main character, imbalance, solution
* Middle: developing situation, giving examples, including data, discuss potential options, illustrating the benefit
* End: call to action

Making Successful Presentations at Work

* For your customers or clients
* For your boss
* For your co-workers
* For community leaders or groups

Job Hunting Tips – Leading firm in Finance

* We invite a team leader in finance to share their needs in work and provide job hunting tips for students in the related industry.

Job Hunting Tips – Leading firm in E-commerce

* We invite a team leader in one of the top e-commerce firms to share their needs in work and provide job hunting tips for students in the related industry.

Job Hunting Tips – Leading Firm in Social Media

* We invite a team leader in one of the top social-media firms to share their needs in work and provide job hunting tips for students in the related industry.

Final Project: Presenting with Precision and Influence I
Final Project: Presenting with Precision and Influence II
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
Knaflic, Cole Nussbaumer. Storytelling with data : a data visualization guide for business professionals. Hoboken, New Jersey : Wiley
Kolin, Philip. Successful writing at work. Boston MA: Cengrage Learning.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Machine Learning for Business II
courses.description: As a second part of machine learning for business, this course provides a holistic overview of advanced machine learning and artificial intelligence models, as well as their mathematical and programming background. It covers, together with others, some commonly used machine learning and deep learning methods such as support vector machine, ensemble models, stacked generalization, and deep learning models. This course emphasizes understanding the intuition behind the methods and on applying them to business practices. It helps build hands-on experiences by using business data and Python, an analytics software package. Taking the first part and having certain coding knowledge will be needed for this course, and a decent familiarity with basic quantitative content (such as linear algebra, optimization, and probability/statistics) will also be required.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Business Analytics; MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Information Science & Technology Management;Pre-requisite: DOTE6756
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Support Vector Machine & Support Vector Regression
2. Decision Tree Model
3. Bagging and Random Forest
4. Gradient Boosting Machine
5. Stacked Generalization
6. Feedforward Neural Network
7. Recurrent Neural Network
8. Convolutional Neural Network
9. Natural Language Processing I
10. Natural Language Processing II
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: “An Introduction to Statistical Learning – with Applications in Python” by Gareth James, Daniela Witten, Trevor Hastie, Robert Tibshirani, and Jonathon Taylor.
courses.recommended_readings: “Deep Learning with Python” by François Chollet.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Business Forecasting
courses.description: This course provides students with principles and methods in forecasting for managerial planning. Major topics include multiple regression analysis, time series analysis with emphasis on smoothing techniques, decomposition methods, and Box-Jenkins procedures and indicator forecasting. Applications of the methods to both short-term and long-term forecasting to business, industries and national business trends are also emphasized.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Business Analytics
courses.course_syllabus: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Project Management
courses.description: This course covers the management of projects. A major focus is on how to manage various projects to successful completion within the constraints of resources and time. Included in the contents are the frameworks for proposal writing and planning, monitoring and controlling, and performance evaluation. Various project management techniques are covered including PERT/CPM and project appraisal. Case studies and field projects as well as lectures will be used as teaching methods.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes:
On completion of this course, students should be able to:
• demonstrate a basic understanding of the theories, concepts and principles of project management with reference to the Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) published by PMI
• articulate the essential components of the project management initiating and planning process, and appreciate the application of project management and organisational behaviour theories in managing projects
courses.course_syllabus: • project management principles & the Project Management Institute (PMI) framework covering TEN Knowledge Areas including integration, scope, time, cost, quality, HR, communications, risk, procurement and stakeholder management
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• There are Group Home Assignment presentation at class for feedback from lecturer and peers, as well as discussion of reference solution to Group Homework Assignments
• Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: Text Book: Kathy Schwalbe, “Managing Information Technology Projects”
courses.recommended_readings: Reference Book: Project Management Institute (USA), “A guide to project management body of knowledge”.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Database and Big Data Management
courses.description: This course focuses on both business data and contemporary big data modeling and management. We will examine the different natures of data and big data, selection and representation as well as use of suitable methods and tools for storing and accessing them. Topics such as data integrity, DBMS, data warehousing, NoSQL and MapReduce are covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics; or MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt
courses.course_syllabus:
Possible syllabus
- The concept of data integration and the database approach
- Relational data model & normalization schema, integrity rules and implementation
- Structured Query Language
- Semantic data modeling
- Databases and the Internet
- Data warehousing & big data
- Capturing social media data & NoSQL

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Information Systems Analysis and Auditing
courses.description: This course provides students with knowledge and experience of analyzing the essential aspects of information systems in the real world. Emphases will be placed on the object-oriented analysis techniques using the Unified Modeling Language. Various key business activities will be discussed. This course will also explain the importance of business IS controls in contemporary IT governance. A business framework for the management of enterprise IS will be investigated.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) Describe the classification of information systems
(2) Analyze various aspects of information systems using Unified Modeling Language
(3) Understand the concepts of information systems controls
(4) Identify the basic components in conducting information systems audit
courses.course_syllabus:
- Business information systems life cycle
- Main components in feasibility study
- IT cost estimation
- Introduction to information system modeling
- Analysis using Unified Modeling Language
- Major components in IT Control
- Brief introduction to the COBIT framework
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
- Dull, R.B., Gelinas, U.J., & Wheeler, P.R. Accounting Information Systems: Foundations in Enterprise Risk Management.
- Fowler, M. UML Distilled - A Brief Guide to the Standard Object Modeling Language.

courses.description: This course aims to train students to extract patterns in vast amounts of data and discover actionable insights. It emphasizes the current issues, methodologies, practices, and emerging trends in machine learning. Students will learn key machine learning techniques to address existing business problems in today’s information-rich environments. Upon completing this course, students will build their analytical capabilities to use data for innovative business solutions. We will use Python as a language tool for machine learning during the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:

1. Understand basic concepts and principles related to machine learning
2. Understand key data preprocessing tasks
3. Understand major machine learning techniques
4. Apply Python acquired from hands-on lab exercises to various machine learning cases
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction of data, algorithms and related business applications

- Concepts of data preparation

- Clustering techniques using k-means and its variants

- Regression techniques using linear regression

- Classification techniques using logistic regression and decision trees

- Concepts of neural networks

- Performance evaluation

courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

a. Data Science for Business: What You Need to Know about Data Mining and Data-analytic Thinking, 1e, by Foster Provost and Tom Fawcett. O'Reilly Media, ISBN-10: 1449361323, ISBN-13: 978-1449361327

b. Data Mining for Business Analytics: Concepts, techniques, and applications in Python, by Galit Shmueli, Peter C. Bruce, Peter Gedeck, and Nitin R. Patel. Wiley, ISBN-10: 1119549841, ISBN-13: 978-1119549840

c. Python for Data Analysis: Data Wrangling with Pandas, NumPy, and IPython, 2e, by Wes McKinney, O'Reilly Media, ISBN-10: 1491957662, ISBN-13: 978-1491957660

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Mobile and Web Applications Development
courses.description: This course provides students with the basic knowledge to design and develop Android applications for mobile devices. Students will work directly with the Java programming language and the latest Android developer tools, with the goal of enabling students to produce fully functional prototypes independently. This course will also place some emphasis on developing web applications using JavaScript. The basic concepts of client server architecture and simple Java Server Pages (JSP) will also be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Information & Technology Management
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
(1) understand the basic constructs in Java programming.
(2) develop the mobile applications using Android integrated development environment.
(3) explain the basic rationale of the concepts in n-tier Web applications, both in client- and server-sides.
(4) identify the major features of JavaScript in user experience (UX) design.
(5) prepare themselves for real-world mobile and Web applications from design to implementation.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Mobile and Web applications using Java
- Basic elements/control flows in Java
- Basic components of an Android application
- Android applications development platform
- Event handling in Android
- Games, graphics, animation and multimedia in Android
- Concepts of JavaScript, XML, CSS, Ajax, and their libraries
- Concepts of database and Java Server Pages (JSP)
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
Burnette, Ed. Hello, Android: Introducing Google's Mobile Development Platform.
Deitel, P. et al. Android: How to Program. Pearson.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Cyber Security

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G01

courses.description: This course provides an overview of the threats to networked organizations. Students will learn and understand the key issues associated with cyber space security, skills required to respond to security incidents, and knowledge needed to design security systems and protect security intrusions. Its coverage includes a variety of concepts and topics related to the securing of networked, cloud, and mobile processing environments.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc in Information & Technology Management
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing the course, students should be able to: (1) assess the current security landscape and the likely consequences of security failures; (2) apply the practices, technologies, and protocols of cyber security to secure business operations; (3) assess the security challenges in the virtual, cloud, and mobile processing environments; (4) understand the legal, ethical, and regulatory issues associated with cyber security policy development, implementation, and administration.
courses.course_syllabus:
Possible topics include:
• Physical and system security (such as access control, user authentication, malicious software, and operating system security)
• Network security (such as encryption, intrusion detection and prevention, and firewalls)
• Security protocols and standards
• Database and cloud computing security
• Wireless security
• Security management and planning
• Legal and ethical aspects of security
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Conklin, W.A. and White, G. Principles of Computer Security.
• Whitman, W. and Mattord, H. Principles of Information Security.
• Stallings, W. and Brown, L. Computer Security: Principles and Practices.

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Technology Field Study
courses.description: This course consists of preparatory assignments in readings and a written study plan, followed by a five-day residential program to Silicon Valley, California or similar Science Parks in Asia. The course is concluded with a written report and an oral presentation. The goal in taking classroom sessions abroad is to expose our graduate students to a wide spectrum of issues related to IT business, which includes research and development, company culture, and ways to manage a technology company. The issues are highlighted through lectures or seminars by university professors, and visits to world class companies or research and development centres. Students will have chance to discuss with top executives from these companies. Through this course, students will be able to understand the strategies companies adopted, and solutions in tackling business issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will recognize the reasons of the success of IT businesses in Silicon Valley or similar Science Parks.
2. Students will be able to learn the strategies adopted by the firms we visited.
courses.course_syllabus: To be decided by course teacher
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Supply Chain and Logistics Management
courses.description: This course covers the concepts, insights, practical tools, and decision support systems for the effective management of the supply chain. This course will convey both the intuitions behind many key supply chain and logistics management concepts and to provide simple techniques that can be used to analyze various aspects of the supply chain and logistics management. The role of supply chain and logistics management in the age of eBusiness will be addressed. Through readings and case studies, we will identify the current and prospective supply chain practices.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Busienss Analytics
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Framework: Supply Chain Design, Planning & Operation
2. Designing the Supply Chain Network: Facility Decisions
3. Supply Chain Planning
4. Managing Inventories
5. Managing Transportation
6. E-Business and the Supply Chain
7. Sourcing and Coordination
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: “Supply Chain Management: Strategy, Planning, & Operation,” Chopra & Meindl (C&M).
courses.recommended_readings: “The New Science of Retailing: How Analytics are Transforming the Supply Chain and Improving Performance,” M. Fisher and A. Raman

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Strategy and Innovation Management
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide a solid grounding to students interested in managing various aspects of the innovation process and understanding it better from a policy perspective. The course is divided into two parts. Broadly, the first two-thirds of the course focuses more on analytic and strategic frameworks for managing innovation. This segment examines patterns of technological change and their impacts, planning for technological transitions, means for capturing economic benefits from innovation, and planning of innovation projects over time. The last third of the course examines more organizational issues involved in implementing strategies. These issues include management of teams and partnerships, learning within and across projects, the manager's role in forecasting and funding, directing and stopping innovation projects, technological entrepreneurship, and barriers to innovation. Case studies, both written and video-based, are used extensively to illustrate a range of technologies and the problems associated with developing them and bringing them to market.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in EMBA (Chinese)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:
a. Take innovation policy from theory to practice
b. Cultivate individual’s innovative mind set from within and without
c. Conduct effective innovation management
courses.course_syllabus: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher

courses.subject: DOTE
courses.title: Enterprise Resource Planning
courses.description: Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) is an integrated information technology to manage company-wide business processes. The topics include two aspects: enterprise resource planning system and the ERP project implementation issues. This course will also introduce the evolution of ERP, concepts and applications of ERP. The topics of enterprise systems will mainly brief on the core modules along the value chain such as product development, order fulfillment, production and others. Finally, the "ERP and beyond" will address how the latest developments of ERP can be extended to fulfill the new demand of more enterprise initiatives. Students will be requested to work on a group project.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, the students are expected to
1. comprehend the concept / theory of enterprise resource planning
2. be familiar with an enterprise system, particularly the ERP suite
3. understand the issues for an ERP implementation
4. apprehend the future trends of ERP
courses.course_syllabus:
Unit 1: Introduction to Enterprise Resource Planning
Unit 2: Build an Business Case
Discussion on the ERP Cost and Benefits Analysis of the ERP in “A problematic enterprise”
Unit 3: Business Process Redesign
Unit 4: Value Chain
Unit 5: Change Management
Unit 6: Implementing ERP
Unit 7: Expanding ERP
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: A Case Article: "The Problematic Enterprise" by American Production and Inventory Control Society (APICS)
courses.recommended_readings:
Paige Baltzan, Business Driven Technology
Daniel Drescher, Blockchain Basics: A Non-Technical Introduction in 25 Steps
David L. Olson, Managerial Issues of Enterprise Resource Planning Systems

Upon completing this course, students will develop a skill to summarize the essential ingredients of a paper in a concise way, to develop an original research topic, and to empirically execute the idea using what they have learned in other seminar courses.
courses.course_syllabus: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.feedback_evaluation: Mandatory Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE) is conducted at the end of the course.
courses.required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
courses.recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher
